Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Solar Wind with a Time-dependent, MHD, Interplanetary Scintillation Tomography
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this 3-year SHINE project is to locate heliospheric structures globally around the Sun, determine their relationship to the heliospheric velocity and density, and trace them back toward the Sun in a physically consistent way. This research project is directly related to one of the National Space Weather goals, namely "to determine the connections between eruptive events and the Sun, and to enhance both the understanding and predictions of solar wind geo-effective events." This project would yield a major step forward in the simulation of complex, turbulent gas systems (both charged and neutral) in the inner Solar System and elsewhere. The development of physical models that embrace "coupling complexity" via the self-consistent incorporation of multiple physical processes is viewed as a pivotal development in the different plasma physics areas for the current decade. The research effort will also provide leadership in promoting plasma physics and computational science within the University of Alabama in Huntsville and the University of California in San Diego campuses. Furthermore, through the training of a broad spectrum of students, scientists and engineers, the project will foster Space Physics research within the State of Alabama. The research and EPO agenda of this SHINE project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.


The main objective of this SHINE project is to develop and utilize a new MHD (magnetohydrodynamic) - IPS (interplanetary scintillations) tomography tool of the solar wind (SW) in order to investigate the evolution of the SW plasma and magnetic field, as well as turbulent fluctuations, from distances beyond the critical point outwards to heliocentric distances of 1-5 AU. The team will study the propagation of Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) into the distant SW, paying particular attention to the magnetic field structure inside CMEs, which is of particular importance for geo-effective events. Moreover, by way of performing the numerical simulations, the CMEs will be propagating through a realistic SW background to the points where the distributions will be compared with the spacecraft data. This will allow the researchers to investigate the effect of CMEs and other transient events on the Earth and interplanetary environment, and help formulate the safety requirements for future interplanetary missions. This makes it a valuable asset for their investigation of "the solar cycle dependence of CMEs, including their propagation through and their interaction with the background SW, including the linking of interplanetary and near-Sun phenomena," as stated in the goals of the NSF's SHINE program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview. Simulations of the magnetized solar wind (SW) propagation towards are of great importance for space weather predictions, which are a matter of serious concern for our modern technologically-dependent society. Development of numerical approaches that would simulate time-dependent SW with coronal mass ejections (CMEs) embedded into it is an important step towards our capability to predict CME arrival times at Earth and their geo-effectiveness. Such numerical simulations require three-dimensional boundary conditions.  Earth Observations of interplanetary scintillations (IPS) provide us with a set of data that is used to estimate the SW parameters with reasonably good accuracy. Various tomography techniques have been developed to deconvolve the line-of-sight integration effects ingrained in observations of IPS to improve the accuracy of SW reconstructions. Among those, the time-dependent tomography developed at the University of California, San Diego (UCSD) is well known for its remarkable accuracy in reproducing the SW speed and density at Earth by iteratively fitting a kinematic solar wind model to observations of IPS and near-Earth spacecraft measurements. The goal of this proposal was to combine the IPS tomography with an MHD model of the SW propagation. This approach would not only serve the prediction purposes, but additionally provide distributions of plasma and magnetic field in the inner heliosphere.

Intellectual merits. We have created an infrastructure that allows us to perform SW simulations starting either from the solar surface or from any distance beyond the critical surface of the Sun, where the SW flow becomes superfast magnetosonic. The boundary conditions at the solar surface are obtained using synoptic magnetograms from Wilcox Solar Observatory and National Solar Observatory, and Solar Dynamics Observatory observations. This was done to facilitate simulations based on the IPS data, which provide us with the time-dependent velocity distributions only. We have proposed to use density-velocity and temperature-velocity correlations derived from Ulysses data. This made it possible to have different correlation formulae in the fast and slow solar wind and also take into account the differences in solar cycles. We have implemented an interface that allows the UAH-developed Multi-Scale Fluid-Kinetic Simulation Suite (MS-FLUKSS) to use the boundary conditions at the inner boundary to perform simulations outward, toward Earth and beyond. MS-FLUKSS has been extensively validated against other numerical models, e.g., the predictive Science Magnetohydrodynamics Around a Sphere (MAS) model. In addition, MS-FLUKSS has been extended by adding the possibility to treat the SW turbulence and non-thermal (pickup) ions in the outer heliosphere. The model have demonstrated an excellent agreement with Ulysses, Voyager, and New Horizons observations. The forward modeling based on Ooty (India) IPS measurements confirmed the necessity of an iterative procedure to obtain reliable results. We have created an operational MHD-IPS model, where MS-FLUKSS results are iterated with the IPS tomography procedures. IPS data obtained from the ISEE (Formerly STELab) radio telescopes in Nagoya, Japan were primarily used. The distribution of magnetic field at the source surface were derived by a technique developed in UCSD, which is based on NSO magnetograms as inputs to the Stanford Current-Sheet Source Surface model. Farther from the Sun, the magnetic field are reproduced in the MHD formulation. The iterative 3-DMS-FLUKSS/IPS model was able to fit in situ

measurements fairly well. However, it occasionally tends to increase peaks related to stream interaction somewhat above the measured values. This is in contrast to ENLIL/IPS simulations. These differences between MS-FLUKSS and MAS, on the one hand, and ENLIL, on the other hand, are well-known. The source of these differences is being investigated and will be addressed in subsequent versions of the code.  

Broader impact.  In addition to space weather related merits of the proposal, the project made it possible to create a robust, science-based, Sun-to-Earth model of the heliosphere based on the mathematically-consistent, characteristic approach at lower corona. The project supported, in part, two postdoctoral researchers, at UCSD and UAH. It also supported a graduate student at UAH. In additions, two undergraduate students participated in the project funded through the NSF REU program. The project provided a leap forward in the computation and simulation of complex charged and neutral gas systems, especially in Alabama as an EPSCoR state.  Participating young researchers have been exposed to modern theories and the most advanced methods of space measurements. The results were disseminated through publications and scientific presentations. MS-FLUKSS is in the process of transition to the Community-coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC), whereas the UCSD tomography is already there. This increases the opportunities of other researchers to use and improve the models.
